awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: PowerMeter: Tracking Energy Usage in the Clouds
awd_abstract_narration:
Workload consolidation on virtualized datacenters is one common  
technique used to manage the power usage and energy efficiency of  
cloud platforms. However, current solutions limit the available  
insight into exactly how energy is consumed by the various cloud  
tenants. 

In order to address this gap, this research develops PowerMeter ? a  
set of mechanisms and tools that make it possible to track energy  
usage in virtualized cloud infrastructures, on granularity of  
individual VMs, or sets of VMs corresponding to a specific cloud  
tenant, e.g., a customer or an application. PowerMeter is developed  
for a 3000-core fully instrumented datacenter prototype and a 1000- 
core system based on newest-generation technology, and is evaluated  
using representative workload mixes based on popular cloud  
applications and publicly available cloud traces. PowerMeter will  
provide currently missing capabilities for dynamically assessing in- 
datacenter/in-cloud energy usage, necessary to enable energy usage  
transparency and accountability to cloud customers, to understand the  
opportunities for improved energy efficiency in virtualized cloud  
systems, and for further development of management methods for energy- 
efficient datacenters.

por.por_cntn:
It is well known that projected increases in the power consumption of datacenters and servers in the US and worldwide continues to grow, and represents approximately 2% of the world's electricity consumption. This not only significantly contributes to increased carbon dioxide emissions, but also may requires the equivalent of an additional 45 coal power plants to satisfy the US demand alone. In response to these trends, researchers in industry and academia are actively developing solutions to curtail datacenter systems' growth in energy demand. One solution with wide adoption is that of consolidating workloads on fewer virtualized physical resources, a model further adopted and advertised by Cloud Computing. 

 

However, there remain several challenges in order to realize the energy-saving opportunities offered by consolidating workloads onto cloud platforms. First, companies are encouraged or even required to demonstrate that they are carbon neutral, so it is important for them to assess their carbon footprint in the cloud. Current cloud platforms, however, are not able to provide such information to customers, or to allow them to assess their workload's energy consumption, or to permit energy-conscious customers to select the most energy-efficient option for their workloads among multiple potential cloud offerings. Second, improved insights into the energy usage of specific workloads, belonging to a single client or representing certain class of applications, can allow cloud operators both to develop more effective management policies and to offer more meaningful billing services.

 

Intellectual Merit: Addressing these gaps, the PowerMeter project developed an approach, along with accompanying mechanisms and tools, for enabling cloud providers to establish a fine-grained energy metering infrastructure. This enables better understanding of the energy usage in virtualized datacenters and cloud infrastructures, tracking of per-virtual machine (VM) or per-set of VMs (i.e., per application distributed across a VM ensemble, or per cloud tenant) energy usage, and provides the necessary support for development of new methods for more energy-efficient datacenters. Specifically, the project developed PowerMeter,

a set of mechanisms and tools that make it possible to track energy usage in virtualized cloud infrastructures, integrated with the popular OpenStack cloud management infrastructure, and released to the community. PowerMeter enabled gathering of detailed insights into the energy- and cost-efficiency for cloud infrastructure (servers, including with GPUs, and building management systems) and popular cloud applications, and provided support for novel dynamic methods for load and temperature management of datacenters. It is being used by a local start up developing algorithms and infrastructure for dynamic management of the cooling infrastructure in datacenters, and through that, it is presently deployed and evaluated in several real-world hosting datacenters.

 

Broader Impact: The technical broader impact of this project is that it created open source technology enabling for new insights and new dynamic management methods for cloud and virtualized datacenters, useful for understanding and improving power- and energy-related metrics, as well as more broadly for metrics related to reliability and performance. By being leveraged in start ups commercializing such management methods, it indirectly contributes to creation of new employment opportunities and revenue streams. The project contributed to training and talent creation: several graduate students, including four women, were supported through the project, or were involved in the development and evaluation of PowerMeter through their graduate research projects, or special projects part of the courses. The skills they obtained directly contributed to their employment opportunities, as all of them ultimately accepted full time positions directly related to datacenter and energy management, at cloud technology companies such as Facebook, Google, VMware, Amazon, Microsoft, Intel, Arista, and Yahoo. Additional broader impact was achieved through outreach and dissemination activities, such as presentations to technical audiences at several of these companies, and to industry events targeting datacenter operators, and to presentations and publications in conferences and research outlets.

Modified by: Ada Gavrilovska
